title: Thompson (2011) vs Koutsoumpis (2021): Do H-stripes slim vs plain?

source_a.author: Thompson 2011 Exp 3
source_a.finding: H-striped cylinder = IDENTICAL width to plain. Zero effect.

source_b.author: Koutsoumpis 2021 Exp 1
source_b.finding: H-striped dress = THINNER than plain (d=0.61, p<.001)

resolution: Cylinders are uniform; human bodies have non-uniform curvature that creates directional effects absent on cylinders. Koutsoumpis more ecologically valid. H-vs-plain effect exists on bodies but weaker than H-vs-V (x0.3 multiplier).
kridha_implication: Apply 0.3x multiplier when comparing striped vs plain (not striped vs opposite-stripe)

title: Thompson (2011) vs Taya & Miura (2007): Do vertical stripes slim 3D forms?

source_a.author: Taya & Miura 2007
source_a.finding: V-stripes increase perceived 3D depth -> make cylinders NARROWER

source_b.author: Thompson 2011
source_b.finding: V-stripes make 3D cylinders and mannequins WIDER (up to 10.7%)

resolution: Thompson directly tested and found Oppel-Kundt widening dominates on actual 3D objects. Taya & Miura's depth-shrinkage may only operate when depth is AMBIGUOUS (2D pictures). Li & Zaidi (2000) undermines Taya & Miura's theoretical basis.
kridha_implication: Assume Thompson correct (V-stripes widen) but carry hidden variable for depth-from-texture on highly curved regions

title: Lab studies vs Swami & Harris (2012): THE fundamental disagreement

source_a.author: Thompson, Koutsoumpis, Ashida (lab)
source_a.finding: H-stripes make bodies look THINNER (d=0.37 to d=1.83)

resolution: NOT a methodological disagreement — measures two different things. Lab = PERCEPTUAL effects (optical illusions). Swami = JUDGMENT effects (perception + memory + cultural belief). Both correct in their context.
kridha_implication: Two scoring modes needed: e-commerce (perceptual coefficients primary, COGNITIVE_OVERRIDE_WEIGHT=0.30) and real-world prediction (cultural belief dominant, COGNITIVE_OVERRIDE_WEIGHT=0.60)

title: Koutsoumpis (2021) vs Hu et al. (2020): Dark clothing in real world

source_a.author: Koutsoumpis 2021
source_a.finding: Dark clothing slims d=0.35-0.58; on dark bg d=1.27

source_b.author: Hu et al. 2020
source_b.finding: Dark clothing reduces perceived weight 'slightly'; H-stripes NO effect

resolution: Koutsoumpis = controlled max-sensitivity conditions. Hu = real-world noise. Small perceptual effects (0.3-1.3%) barely detectable in noisy real-world data. Lab values are UPPER BOUNDS.
kridha_implication: Apply real_world_attenuation multiplier of 0.3-0.6 to all lab-derived coefficients

title: Sidhu (2021) vs pure luminance model: Color anomalies

source_a.author: Koutsoumpis luminance model
source_a.finding: Width is monotonic function of luminance (darker=slimmer)

source_b.author: Sidhu 2021
source_b.finding: Grey (L*~50) WIDER than white (L*~90+). Red (L*~35) slim as black (L*~10).

resolution: UNRESOLVED. Luminance is necessary but NOT sufficient. Saturation/chroma and 'red effect' (Elliot & Niesta 2008) independently modulate perceived size.
kridha_implication: Hue-correction terms needed. Currently estimated with very low confidence (2/5). Tractable A/B testing target.

title: Ashida (2013) vs Imai (1982): Size of body-size reversal

source_a.author: Ashida 2013
source_a.finding: Fat figure: Helmholtz weakened to near-zero (PSE~0, NS)

source_b.author: Imai 1982
source_b.finding: Overweight figure: V-stripes 15.37% thinner than H-stripes (full reversal)

resolution: Body width difference (Imai wider W:H>0.70 vs Ashida ~0.60-0.65) + task demand (Imai rating scales inflate effect) + gender (Imai male, Ashida female). Crossover W:H~0.52 is interpolated from these two conflicting data points — could be 0.45 to 0.65.
kridha_implication: CRITICAL uncertainty. The most dangerous parameter in the model. Validating crossover with Kridha data is single highest-priority research task.

title: Thompson Exp 1 height vs width asymmetry

source_a.finding: H-stripes must be 4.5% wider than V-stripes to look equal WIDTH

source_b.finding: V-stripes must be 7.1% taller than H-stripes to look equal HEIGHT

resolution: Not a contradiction — genuine asymmetry revealing mechanism. Vertical-Horizontal Illusion (Kunnapas 1955) adds to Helmholtz for height but not width. H-stripes create BOTH Helmholtz elongation AND VHI height enhancement.
kridha_implication: Use 4.5% for width predictions (conservative) and 7.1% for height. Separate height_effect and width_effect outputs.

title: Avoid horizontal stripes — the biggest wrong call in fashion
practitioner_says: Horizontal stripes make you look wider (universal advice since 1813 Japan, 1970s+ Western)
resolution: Popular wisdom correct for ~30% of bodies (wider W:H), wrong for ~70% (thinner W:H). Additionally, Swami real-world finding suggests cultural belief may override perceptual slimming in social contexts.

title: Wear dark colors to look slimmer — right principle, wrong magnitude
practitioner_says: Black is slimming (treated as major effect)
academic_says: Black slims 0.19% on white backgrounds (NS). Up to 1.33% on dark backgrounds. Popular advice overstates by 10-50x.
resolution: Technically correct but effect is TINY in e-commerce contexts. Meaningful only in dark environments. Practitioners intuit OTHER benefits (hides texture, reduces strain lines, psychological confidence) that are real but unmeasured.
who_is_right: Both — practitioners right about direction, wrong about magnitude via pure optics. Practitioners capture unmeasured functional benefits.

title: Vertical lines elongate — right mechanism, wrong application
academic_says: V-stripes make bodies WIDER (Thompson Exp 3). 8-12+ vertical elements trigger Oppel-Kundt widening.
resolution: 1-3 vertical LINES (princess seams) produce HVI elongation (-2-4%). But 30+ vertical STRIPES (pinstripes) produce Oppel-Kundt widening (+3-7%). Advice conflates 'lines' with 'stripes'.
who_is_right: Practitioners right for FEW lines, wrong for MANY stripes

title: Match pattern scale to body scale — zero evidence
practitioner_says: Petite=small prints, plus-size=large prints (stated as settled fact)
academic_says: No peer-reviewed study has tested this. Zero quantified evidence.
resolution: UNRESOLVED. Could be correct, incorrect, or body-type-dependent.

title: Warm colors make you look bigger — backwards for red
practitioner_says: Avoid warm colors (red, orange, yellow) to look slimmer
academic_says: Advancing/receding affects DEPTH not WIDTH (PMC11652407 2024). Width: 0.00. Red actually makes bodies look SLIMMER than luminance predicts (Sidhu 2021).
resolution: Popular advice backwards for red. Warm/cool is a depth effect, not a size effect.
who_is_right: Academic — practitioners fundamentally wrong about mechanism

title: Plus-size pinstripe recommendation failure
practitioner_says: Plus-size pinstripe blouses are slimming (widely recommended)
academic_says: Stripe slimming (-1.42%) nearly perfectly cancelled by Oppel-Kundt widening (+1.40%) when vertical line count exceeds 8-12. Net: -0.20% (essentially zero).
resolution: Popular recommendation produces near-zero net effect due to opposing mechanisms.

pattern: Rule correct for SOME bodies, wrong for others
engine_response: Body-measurement-conditional scoring. Rule becomes function with thresholds, not a constant.
Use RICHER INPUT DATA. Continuous measurements instead of categories. Contour quality instead of just circumference.
GOAL-AWARE SCORING. Every score relative to user's stated goal, not assumed ideal.

title: The Stripes War — The Single Biggest Disagreement in All of Fashion

source_a.camp: Popular Wisdom (200+ years, since 1813 Japanese beauty handbook)
source_a.claim: Horizontal stripes make you look wider. Vertical stripes make you look slimmer. Always wear vertical stripes if you want to appear thinner.

source_b.claim: Horizontal stripes make figure appear NARROWER. H-striped figure must be 5.8% broader to match V-striped perceived width. On 3D mannequins: 10.7% wider for perceived equality.

source_c.claim: H-stripes make bodies look WIDER in real-world encounters assessed from memory (d=0.63). Corroborates popular belief, CONTRADICTS Helmholtz.

source_d.claim: Helmholtz effect is body-size dependent. H-stripes make SLIM figures slimmer. Effect weakens and may REVERSE on larger figures.

source_e.claim: H-stripes AND lower luminance BOTH independently produce thinning effect, larger when combined.

resolution: EVERYONE IS PARTIALLY RIGHT. Resolution is BODY-SIZE DEPENDENT.

below_30th_percentile.note: Slim figure: Helmholtz at full strength

50th-70th_percentile.note: Above average: very weak, approaching zero

70th-85th_percentile.note: Full figure: REVERSED — H-stripes now WIDEN

above_85th_percentile.note: Very full figure: moderate widening from H-stripes

unified_model.real_world_brief_explanation: In brief real-world encounters, SOCIAL BELIEF ('horizontal = wider') actually OVERRIDES perceptual effect: 1) People assess from memory not direct perception; 2) Prior beliefs contaminate judgment; 3) Attention not focused on body width

rules: NEVER give blanket advice 'avoid horizontal stripes' — wrong for ~50% of population
Below 30th percentile width: H-stripes HELP (score +0.15 to +0.25). INVERTS popular advice.
30th-70th percentile: Effect near ZERO in either direction (score -0.05 to +0.05). Orientation barely matters.
Above 70th percentile: H-stripes may have MILD widening (score -0.10 to -0.20). Here ONLY is popular wisdom approximately correct.
Stripe WIDTH and DENSITY matter more than orientation
LUMINANCE CONTRAST matters as much as orientation. Dark H-stripes may be MORE slimming than light V-stripes.

title: The Black Clothing Paradox — 'Black Is Slimming' But Is It?

source_a.claim: Black is the most slimming color. Always wear black to look thinner.

source_b.claim: Mostly confirmed but actual magnitude approximately 2-5% reduction in perceived girth. Popular wisdom overestimates by 2-5x.
source_b.additional: Black and red attracted highest body attractiveness AND slimmer body size ratings. Green and grey induced LOWEST attractiveness. Women with higher BMI significantly more likely to choose black — confounding effect.

source_c.claim: Black is slimming BUT can make you look shapeless. Depends on cut and fit.

hourglass_WHR_below_0.75.reason: All-black eliminates contrast needed to SHOW waist-hip differential. Body reads as dark column at widest width. Hourglass disappears inside monochrome.

rectangle_apple_WHR_above_0.85.reason: Minimal shape to lose. Dark monochrome 'column' effect DESIRABLE.

the_paradox: Black is LESS slimming on bodies most conventionally 'slim' (hourglasses) and MORE slimming on bodies least conventionally 'slim' (rectangles/apples). Standard rule backwards for most curved body types.

engine_impact.never_say: 'Wear black to look slimmer' without qualification

title: The Body Type Category Fallacy — Foundation of Fashion Advice Is Flawed

source_a.claim: Identify your body type (apple, pear, hourglass, rectangle, inverted triangle), then follow rules for your type.

source_b.claim: Body type category system is crude approximation that fails in multiple ways.

failure_modes.failure: Most Women Don't Fit Clean Categories
failure_modes.evidence: 46% rectangle, 20% pear, 14% apple, only 8% hourglass. Hourglass (most fashion advice, most design attention) represents < 1 in 12 women. Rectangle (nearly half) is drastically underserved.

failure_modes.example: Two 'pears': Woman A (34-27-39, WHR 0.69) and Woman B (34-32-37, WHR 0.86). Same category advice would be WRONG for at least one. A-line works for A (clear waist/hips) but B has barely any hip to 'balance.'

Two 'hourglasses' (36-26-36): Woman C at 5'0" (hips are 58% of height = dramatically curvy) and Woman D at 5'9" (hips are 52% = proportionally balanced). SAME measurements, radically different visual proportions.

failure_modes.failure: Categories Ignore Muscle vs. Fat Distribution
failure_modes.reference: Exception SF-06: Two women with identical bust-waist-hip need OPPOSITE recommendations based on composition.

rules: NEVER use body type categories as primary classification — lossy compression of continuous data
Use CONTINUOUS MEASUREMENTS AND RATIOS: WHR, bust-waist differential, shoulder-hip differential, height-to-hip ratio, torso-to-leg ratio
If UI needs body type label, use as STARTING POINT then immediately individualize
Factor in HEIGHT as first-class dimension
Factor in USER ASPIRATION as first-class dimension

title: Fitted vs. Loose — The Sizing Paradox

source_a.claim: Wear loose clothing to hide your body if you want to look thinner.

source_b.claim: Fitted clothing actually makes you look SLIMMER than loose clothing. Garment showing shape is more flattering than one hiding it in shapeless volume.

resolution: CONTOUR QUALITY PROBLEM, not a size problem.

smooth_convex_contours.fitted_result: Shows actual shape which is smooth → FLATTERING
smooth_convex_contours.loose_result: Adds volume making body appear LARGER

irregular_contours.loose_result: Smooths over irregularities → body appears smoother

resolution_detail.critical_insight: Hiding SIZE → fitted better (shows actual smaller width). Hiding TEXTURE → loose better (smooths irregularities).

smoothness_above_0.7.recommendation: FITTED — smooth contours benefit from being shown

smoothness_0.4_to_0.7.recommendation: SKIMMING — light ease smooths minor issues while showing shape

smoothness_below_0.4.recommendation: RELAXED — enough ease to smooth irregularities without overwhelming volume

engine_impact: Engine needs CONTOUR DATA not just circumference. Until available, use proxies: user indicating 'concerned about stomach area' → assume irregular contour. Default: recommend SKIMMING fit (1-3" ease) as safest middle ground.

title: Dress to Minimize vs. Dress to Celebrate — The Philosophical Contradiction

source_a.claim: Identify 'problem areas' and minimize/conceal/distract. Goal: illusion of 'ideal' body.

source_b.claim: No 'problem areas.' All bodies beautiful. Fashion should celebrate, not conceal. Goal: self-expression and confidence.

resolution: Not a factual disagreement — a VALUES disagreement. Has direct implications for scoring engine.

engine_impact.score_meaning: +1.0 should mean 'maximally achieves YOUR stated goal' not 'looks like ideal body'
engine_impact.example: Puff sleeve on wide shoulders: If goal 'narrower': score -0.70. If goal 'showcase': score +0.70. If 'no_preference': score 0.
engine_impact.resolves_SF06: Resolves muscular body exception systemically rather than as special case. Engine doesn't need separate 'muscular body' code path — needs goal-aware scoring function for ALL bodies.

title: The Waist Placement Wars — Practitioners Disagree With Each Other

source_a.claim: Natural waist is the most flattering placement for everyone.

source_b.camp: Camp B (popular in Asian fashion markets)
source_b.claim: High-waisted clothing universally more flattering because it makes legs appear longer.

source_c.camp: Camp C (experienced practitioners with real bodies)
source_c.claim: Ideal waist placement depends entirely on torso-to-leg ratio. No universal answer.

resolution: Camp C is right. Resolution depends on current_leg_proportion vs golden_ratio_target (0.618).

leg_proportion_0.55_to_0.60.note: Legs slightly short of golden ratio

leg_proportion_below_0.50.note: Very short legs relative to torso

engine_impact: NEVER default to 'natural waist is best' — correct for only ~30-40% of women
Compute torso-to-leg ratio from body scan data. Score every waist placement.
High-waist popularity in Asian fashion is population-level response to different average proportions, not a trend. Engine must be proportion-aware across demographics.

title: Monochrome vs. Color Blocking Debate

source_a.claim: Monochrome outfits (single color head to toe) create longest vertical line, make you look tallest/slimmest.

source_b.claim: Strategic color blocking (different colors for different zones) can create better proportions by visually adjusting body boundary readings.

monochrome_better_when: Goal is maximum vertical elongation (petite wanting to appear taller)
Score: elongation +0.35 monochrome vs +0.15 color block
color_blocking_better_when: Body has disproportionate zones (short torso + long legs, or vice versa)
User wants to CREATE proportion (add visual waist, adjust shoulder-hip balance)
Body has strong differential user wants to showcase
Score: proportion balance +0.45 strategic color block vs +0.10 monochrome
insight: Monochrome HOMOGENIZES body into single column. Color blocking SEGMENTS body into zones with independent properties. Want homogeneity (uniform elongation): monochrome. Want segmentation (different treatment per zone): color block.

title: Practitioner Disagreement on Pattern Scale

source_a.claim: Wear patterns proportional to body size. Petite = small prints, larger = larger prints.

source_b.claim: Small prints on large bodies make body look bigger by comparison. Larger women should wear medium-to-large prints.

source_c.claim: Pattern scale should match the FEATURE not the body. Small patterns on minimize areas, large patterns on attention areas.

evidence: One of the LEAST researched areas. No rigorous perceptual science study has definitively resolved pattern scale x body size interaction.
limited_evidence: Very small busy patterns create 'wall of texture' reading as visual mass (supports Camp B concern)
Very large patterns can overwhelm small frame making pattern the focal point (supports Camp A)
Medium-scale patterns seem near-universally safe regardless of body size

engine_impact.future: Kridha data collection (pattern scale x body size x return rates across millions of SKUs) will BUILD evidence academic research hasn't produced.

title: Golden Ratio — Universal or Cultural?

source_a.claim: Golden ratio (1.618) represents ideal body proportions. Legs should be 61.8% of total visual height. Torso-to-total ratio should be 38.2%.

source_b.claim: Preferred body proportions vary significantly across cultures. 0.7 WHR preference is LESS universal than initially claimed (Singh 1993). Preferred WHR varies 0.6 to 0.8+ across cultures. 'Universal' findings heavily biased toward Western samples.

source_c.claim: Uses golden ratio as design principle (pattern grading, garment proportioning) but rarely checks whether it matches actual perceptual preferences across populations.

engine_impact: Use golden ratio as STARTING POINT, not target. Score deviation as continuous function, not binary threshold.
WEIGHT golden ratio score based on user's cultural context. Adjust target proportions for markets with different leg-to-torso preferences.
Golden ratio score should NEVER exceed 30% of total garment score. One signal among many.
Confidence: MEDIUM for Western markets, LOW for global application.

title: Neckline Theory vs. Neckline Practice — What Works vs. What Sells

source_a.claim: V-necks optimal for short necks, boat necks for narrow shoulders, square necks for round faces. Each neckline has a 'best body.'

source_b.claim: Crew necks and round necks outsell V-necks and boat necks by massive margins across ALL body types. 'Theoretically optimal' necklines are NOT what consumers choose.

crew_chosen_because: Works in every context (casual, professional, formal)
Requires no undergarment strategy (no cleavage management)
Familiar — 70%+ of casual tops are crew/round neck
v_neck_avoided_because: Draws attention to bust zone (unwanted for many users)
Unfamiliar to users who default to crew

two_scoring_modes.proportion_optimization: Pure visual proportion math. V-neck might score +0.60.
two_scoring_modes.practical_scoring: Factors in context, comfort, preferences. Same V-neck: -0.20 for 'professional context' + 'minimal bust attention.'

engine_impact.explain_tradeoff: Example: 'Medium V-neck would elongate neck ~1 inch (+0.50), but you prefer covered necklines for work. Scoop neck provides moderate elongation (+0.25) while maintaining coverage.'
engine_impact.rule: Never recommend theoretically optimal garment without checking practical constraints. Best garment user won't wear is worse than 'good enough' garment they will.

title: Arm Coverage Disagreement

source_a.claim: Never show upper arms if they're full.

source_b.claim: Covering arms draws MORE attention to them.

resolution.camp_a_right: Exposed full arms show actual width.
resolution.camp_b_right: OBVIOUS arm covering (shrug only over arms, cardigan at 90F) signals 'I'm hiding my arms,' drawing MORE cognitive attention than simply having bare arms.

optimal: Sleeves that are NATURAL part of garment design, not obviously added to conceal. Dress with built-in 3/4 sleeves draws zero attention. Sleeveless dress + separate arm-covering shrug draws maximum attention.

score_modifiers.season_inappropriate_coverage: -0.20 (e.g., long sleeves in summer signals hiding)

kridha_says: On YOUR body (35th percentile width), horizontal stripes actually make you appear 3% narrower. Wear them.
On YOUR body (defined waist), all-black erases your best feature. Dark bottom + contrast top at waist scores +0.35 vs all-black at -0.15.

generic_advice: You're a pear, so wear A-line
kridha_says: Your hip-to-waist differential is only 3 inches. Standard A-line adds volume you don't need. Straight-leg pant with defined waist scores +0.40 vs A-line at +0.05.
V-neck elongates your neck by ~1 inch, but on your DD bust with stretch fabric, the V will deepen to dividing depth. Scoop neck gives 70% of elongation with zero bust risk.
At your arm length (20 inches), standard '3/4 sleeve' reaches your wrist, functioning as full-length. Look for sleeves labeled 'elbow length' to get actual 3/4 position.
At your height (5'2"), safe zone between knee and calf danger zones is only 1 inch. Above-knee scores +0.75 vs below-knee at -0.10.
